faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Everything you need to know about solar energy

items.q1: How long do solar panels last?
items.a1: Solar panels typically last 25-30 years, with most manufacturers offering 25-year performance warranties. The panels continue to produce electricity beyond this period, though at slightly reduced efficiency.
items.q2: What is the payback period for a solar system?
items.a2: The payback period varies depending on system size, location, and energy costs, typically ranging from 5-8 years. After this period, you essentially get free electricity for the remaining lifespan of the system.
items.q3: Do solar panels work in cloudy weather?
items.a3: Yes, solar panels can generate electricity even on cloudy days, though at reduced efficiency (typically 10-25% of full capacity). Modern panels are designed to capture diffused sunlight effectively.
items.q4: What maintenance do solar systems require?
items.a4: Solar systems require minimal maintenance. Regular cleaning of panels (2-4 times per year) and periodic system inspections are usually sufficient. Most systems include monitoring to alert you to any issues.
items.q5: Can I go completely off-grid with solar?
items.a5: Yes, with an off-grid solar system that includes battery storage, you can achieve complete energy independence. This is ideal for remote locations or areas with unreliable grid access.
items.q6: How much roof space do I need?
items.a6: Typically, you need about 100-200 square feet per kilowatt of solar capacity. A 5kW system (average residential) requires approximately 300-400 square feet of roof space.

onGrid.name: Solar PV Power Generation – On-Grid
onGrid.summary: Grid-connected solar systems that feed excess energy back to the utility grid
onGrid.description: On-grid solar PV systems are connected to the local utility grid, allowing you to feed excess electricity back to the grid and draw power when needed. This system is ideal for locations with reliable grid infrastructure and offers the benefit of net metering, where you can earn credits for excess energy production.
onGrid.howItWorks: Solar panels convert sunlight into DC electricity, which is then converted to AC by the grid-tied inverter. The AC power is used to power your home or business. Excess electricity flows back to the grid through the net meter, spinning it backwards and earning you credits. When solar production is insufficient, you draw power from the grid as usual.

technicalDetails.2: Net meter for bidirectional energy flow

offGrid.name: Solar PV Power Generation – Off-Grid
offGrid.summary: Independent solar systems with battery storage for complete energy autonomy
offGrid.description: Off-grid solar systems operate independently from the utility grid, making them perfect for remote locations or areas with unreliable grid access. These systems include battery storage to ensure continuous power supply even when the sun is not shining.
offGrid.howItWorks: Solar panels generate DC electricity during daylight hours. The charge controller regulates the charging of batteries, preventing overcharging. The batteries store excess energy for use at night or during cloudy days. The inverter converts stored DC energy to AC power for your appliances. When batteries are low, a backup generator can supplement power if included.

technicalDetails.0: Solar panels with high efficiency cells

netMeter.name: Solar PV Power Generation – Net-Meter-System
netMeter.summary: Smart metering system that tracks energy production and consumption
netMeter.description: Net metering systems use advanced smart meters to track both energy production and consumption in real-time. This allows for precise billing and optimal energy management, ensuring you get maximum value from your solar investment.
netMeter.howItWorks: The smart net meter continuously measures electricity flow in both directions. When your solar system produces more power than you consume, the excess flows to the grid and the meter records it. When you need more power than solar provides, you draw from the grid. At the end of the billing period, you pay only for the net energy consumed, or receive credits for excess production.

centralHeating.name: Solar Water Heating Systems – Central
centralHeating.summary: Centralized solar water heating for large buildings and complexes
centralHeating.description: Central solar water heating systems are designed for large buildings, hotels, hospitals, and residential complexes. These systems use a centralized collector array and storage system to provide hot water for multiple units efficiently.
centralHeating.howItWorks: Solar collectors on the roof absorb sunlight and heat a transfer fluid (usually water or glycol). This heated fluid is pumped to a central storage tank where it transfers heat to the water supply. The system includes backup heating for cloudy days. Hot water is distributed to all units through the building's plumbing system.

waterHeater.name: Solar Water Heater
waterHeater.summary: Efficient residential and commercial solar water heating solutions
waterHeater.description: Residential and commercial solar water heaters provide an efficient and cost-effective way to heat water using solar energy. These systems can reduce water heating costs by up to 80% and are available in various configurations to suit different needs.
waterHeater.howItWorks: Solar collectors mounted on the roof absorb solar radiation and heat a transfer fluid. The heated fluid circulates through a heat exchanger in the storage tank, warming the water. A backup electric heating element ensures hot water availability during extended cloudy periods. The system operates automatically with minimal user intervention.

benefits.0: Significant cost savings on hot water

pump.name: Solar Pump
pump.summary: Solar-powered water pumping systems for irrigation and water supply
pump.description: Solar-powered water pumps are ideal for irrigation, livestock watering, and water supply in remote areas. These systems eliminate the need for grid electricity or fuel, making them perfect for sustainable agriculture and rural water supply.
pump.howItWorks: Solar panels generate DC electricity that powers the pump motor directly or through an inverter for AC pumps. The pump draws water from a well, borehole, or surface source and delivers it to a storage tank or directly to the irrigation system. The system operates automatically when sunlight is available, with optional battery backup for continuous operation.

inverter.name: Solar Energy Inverter
inverter.summary: Advanced inverters converting DC solar energy to usable AC power
inverter.description: Solar inverters are the heart of any solar PV system, converting DC electricity from solar panels into AC electricity for use in homes and businesses. Modern inverters feature advanced monitoring, maximum power point tracking (MPPT), and grid integration capabilities.
inverter.howItWorks: Solar panels produce DC electricity with variable voltage and current depending on sunlight conditions. The inverter uses MPPT (Maximum Power Point Tracking) to continuously adjust and extract the maximum power from the panels. It then converts this DC power to stable AC power matching the grid frequency and voltage. Advanced inverters also monitor system performance, detect faults, and can disconnect from the grid during outages for safety.

battery.name: Solar Battery Storage
battery.summary: High-capacity battery systems for energy storage and backup power
battery.description: Solar battery storage systems allow you to store excess solar energy for use during nighttime, cloudy days, or power outages. Modern lithium-ion batteries offer high efficiency, long lifespan, and are essential for off-grid systems and backup power applications.
battery.howItWorks: During daylight hours, excess solar energy charges the battery bank through a charge controller that regulates voltage and current to prevent overcharging. The battery management system (BMS) monitors cell health, temperature, and state of charge. When solar production is insufficient or during outages, the stored energy is discharged through an inverter to power your loads. Modern systems can prioritize critical loads and optimize charging/discharging based on usage patterns.
